title: Alexander Isak and Eddie Howe reshaped attack reigniting Newcastle season
body_text:
By Eddie Howeâ€™s admission, this was â€œa key momentâ€ in Newcastle Unitedâ€™s season.
Fail to win again and the negative momentum that had been building since 2023 began threatened to derail a campaign that had promised so much before New Year. But claim a first Premier League victory in six attempts since January 15 and the dream of Champions League qualification would remain within Newcastleâ€™s hands.

â€œDesperate to winâ€, head coach Howe decided it was time to make radical changes to his starting XI â€” five in total â€” and completely reshape an attack that had delivered only three goals in eight league games. It was the moment to â€œrotate and freshen upâ€ a unit that had gone stale.
The proactive selections for the visit of Wolves were bold and risky â€” Miguel Almiron, previously an ever-present, was dropped to help make way for three players who had managed just 17 top-flight starts between them before Sundayâ€™s match â€” yet the calculated gamble succeeded.
The newcomers reinvigorated a side who have been renowned for their high-intensity, front-foot style, but who have appeared leaden and leggy recently.
The trio of Jacob Murphy, Allan Saint-Maximin and, in particular, Alexander Isak, were everything Almiron and especially Callum Wilson have not been for weeks. They were dynamic, they were powerful and they were extremely direct. Along with Joe Willock, restored to the XI for the first time in three games following injury, Newcastle were athletically superior in every facet.
At times, the front three terrorised a Wolves side who looked technically proficient, if lightweight in comparison. The high press, the overlaps and underlaps, and the constant set-piece threat Newcastle provided was a welcome reminder of what this side have been for much of Howeâ€™s 16 months in charge.
As Isak put it, Newcastle â€œcreated a lot of dangerâ€.
The starting XI also offered a glimpse into a potentially exciting future. For the first time in the Premier League, Bruno Guimaraes, Sven Botman and Isak started together, with the latter delivering a coming-of-age performance.
It was the sort of man-of-the-match display that will lead many fans to wonder whether the Sweden international has now leapfrogged Wilson to become the clubâ€™s first-choice centre-forward.

Isak has the best goals-to-minute ratio of any Newcastle player this season. He has scored four times, from a non-penalty expected goals (xG) return of 3.32, and is averaging 0.56 goals per 90.
It was Isak who led the press, harrying Wolvesâ€™ back four and goalkeeper; it was Isak who galloped down the channels, embarrassing Craig Dawson with his speed and clever running lines; it was Isak who repeatedly gestured to the crowd to raise the noise levels; it was Isak who opened the scoring, with what Howe lauded as â€œthe finish of a traditional Newcastle No 9â€.
